posts.id: Dynamic Programming is one of the hardest concepts_56
posts.text: Dynamic Programming is one of the hardest concepts. But I'll make DP easy for you: Well, here's the list: 1. Fibonacci Sequence - Climbing Stairs - Fibonacci Number - Min Cost Climbing Stairs 2. Kadane's Algorithm - Maximum Subarray - Maximum Sum Circular Subarray - Maximum Product Subarray 3. 0/1 Knapsack - Partition Equal Subset Sum - Target Sum - Last Stone Weight II 4. Unbounded Knapsack - Coin Change - Coin Change 2 - Perfect Squares 5. Longest Common Subsequence (LCS) - Longest Common Subsequence - Delete Operation for Two Strings - Shortest Common Supersequence 6. Longest Increasing Subsequence (LIS) - Longest Increasing Subsequence - Number of Longest Increasing Subsequence - Russian Doll Envelopes 7. Palindromic Subsequence - Longest Palindromic Subsequence - Palindromic Substrings - Minimum Insertion Steps to Make a String Palindrome 8. Edit Distance - Edit Distance - Delete Operation for Two Strings - Minimum ASCII Delete Sum for Two Strings 9. Subset Sum - Partition Equal Subset Sum - Target Sum - Partition to K Equal Sum Subsets 10. String Partition - Word Break - Palindrome Partitioning II - Concatenated Words 11. Catalan Numbers - Unique Binary Search Trees - Generate Parentheses 12. Matrix Chain Multiplication - Minimum Score Triangulation of Polygon - Burst Balloons - Minimum Cost to Merge Stones 13. Count Distinct Ways - Decode Ways - Count Number of Texts 14. DP on Grids - Unique Paths - Minimum Path Sum - Longest Increasing Path in a Matrix 15. DP on Trees - House Robber III - Binary Tree Maximum Path Sum - Binary Tree Cameras 16. DP on Graphs - Cheapest Flights Within K Stops - Find the City With the Smallest Number of Neighbors at a Threshold Distance 17. Digit DP - Count Numbers With Unique Digits - Number of Digit One - Numbers At Most N Given Digit Set 18. Bitmasking DP - Minimum Number of Work Sessions to Finish the Tasks - Fair Distribution of Cookies - Shortest Path Visiting All Nodes 19. Probability DP - Knight Probability in Chessboard - Soup Servings - New 21 Game 20. State Machine DP - Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock With Cooldown - Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock III Itâ€™s not about quantity. Itâ€™s about clarity, consistency, and confidence. You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve built for you: âœ… Notes that are concise and clear âœ… Most-asked questions per topic âœ… Real patterns + approaches to master them ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Ultimate Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ²: Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B WhatsApp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: These 20 tips will solve 95% interview problems. S_36
posts.text: These 20 tips will solve 95% interview problems. Save this post for revision ğŸ”¹ Problem-Solving Techniques 1. Two Pointers - When working from both ends â€” great for pairs, sorting, or partitions. 2. Sliding Window - Fixed or variable-size windows are perfect for max/min subarrays, longest substrings, etc. 3. Prefix Sum + Difference Array - Store running totals to convert range queries to O(1). - Use diff arrays when you need fast range updates. 4. Binary Search on Answer - When brute force is too slow â€” try BS on search space instead of array index. 5. Kadaneâ€™s Algorithm - For max subarray sum â€” also works with tweaks for circular arrays or product variants. ğŸ”¹ Implementation Optimizations 6. Overwrite Instead of Remove - Avoid shifting by replacing in-place (e.g., nums[i++] = nums[j]). 7. Avoid Re-sorting - Sort once only if needed â€” never inside loops. Use pointers or sets for O(n) logic. 8. Use Hashing - Map, Set, Boolean[] are powerful for frequency, uniqueness, or existence checks. 9. Count Arrays for Characters - Use int[26] or int[256] instead of Map<char, int> â€” faster in most languages. 10. Fast I/O - In contests, use faster I/O methods (BufferedReader, Scanner, etc.) to avoid TLE. ğŸ”¹ Debugging & Edge Cases 11. Preserve Input - If not told to modify input, make a copy. Prevents hard-to-trace bugs. 12. Off-by-One Errors - Most common mistake. Use dry runs or print indices to verify loop bounds. 13. Validate Edge Cases - Check for empty arrays, single elements, all negatives, or already sorted inputs. 14. Use Assertive Prints - Print indices, pointers, window start-end, and mid calculations while debugging. 15. Brute First â†’ Optimize - Get a working brute force solution first, then find patterns to optimize. ğŸ”¹ Mindset & Prep Strategy 16. Donâ€™t Memorize Code â€” Memorize Patterns 17. Editorials After Effort â€“ Donâ€™t give up in 10 mins. 18. Solve Variants â€“ One pattern = 5+ problems. 19. Tag Your Mistakes â€“ Pattern > practice. 20. Revisit After 7 Days â€“ Retention > randomness. ğŸ”¹ Quick Hits (Save-worthy tips) - arr.slice() > mutating input - Use Math.max() inside Kadane's - Donâ€™t use .sort() in every subarray question - Set.has() is O(1) â€” use it more - while (left < right) is safer than for (i = 0; i < n; i++) in many logic cases - charCode - 'a'.charCodeAt(0) â†’ great for char-index mapping - Skip rechecking nums[i] === nums[i-1] if already handled - Read constraints â€” they often hint the optimal solution Need a roadmap for DSA? You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve built for you: âœ… Notes that are concise and clear âœ… Most-asked questions per topic âœ… Real patterns + approaches to master them ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Ultimate Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ²: Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B WhatsApp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: Most of us waste months in: 1. Randomly switching _49
posts.text: Most of us waste months in: 1. Randomly switching between platforms 2. Solving questions without understanding the why 3. Confusing quantity with mastery What you really need is depth, patterns, and the right roadmap. Hereâ€™s a list of resources (free & gold standard) and how to use them: â—‰ Tech Interview Handbook â€“ Not just theory, itâ€™s a roadmap with coding templates, behavioral questions, and last-minute cheatsheets. Best for structuring your prep. => https://lnkd.in/gU6kk5eN â—‰ Awesome Interview Questions (GitHub) â€“ A handpicked list of questions across tech stacks. Use this to practice what companies actually ask. => https://lnkd.in/gY-AYpQk â—‰ System Design Primer â€“ Learn the fundamentals of designing scalable systems. Covers HLD + LLD with real-world examples. Must for mid/senior roles. => https://lnkd.in/g6yMEsGv â—‰ Python Algorithm Implementations â€“ Short, clear code snippets to revise common algorithms. Great for pattern recognition and last-minute brushing up. => https://lnkd.in/g7hv9ShZ â—‰ Coding Interview University â€“ A complete learning path from scratch to advanced topics. Perfect for structured self-study if you have 2â€“3 months. => https://lnkd.in/gWnd3n6C â—‰ Front-End Interview Handbook â€“ Tailored for JavaScript, React, and web dev roles. Includes theory, code challenges, and tricky browser-related questions. => https://lnkd.in/gpZpC_ZX â—‰ JavaScript Algorithm Implementations â€“ A quick reference for data structures and algorithms in JS. Helps in interviews where coding language matters. => https://lnkd.in/g9V7d-Ya These repos save time because theyâ€™re organized. Theyâ€™ll teach you patterns, not just problems. But hereâ€™s the catch: Even the best resources fail if you donâ€™t know how to use them. - Which problems first? - When to move from DSA to system design? - How to revise and build confidence? Thatâ€™s why I built my Ultimate DSA Guide â€“ a step by step, beginner to advanced path that simplifies everything: âœ… Pattern-based learning (not brute force solving) âœ… Notes & real examples âœ… Weekly tasks and checkpoints to keep you on track âœ… Interview-focused tips I wish I had earlier ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ² : Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B Whatsapp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: If youâ€™re heading for placements or interviews, yo_90
posts.text: If youâ€™re heading for placements or interviews, you must solve these 60, and youâ€™ll cover 80% of the patterns youâ€™ll face. I wish someone had just handed me this roadmap â€” it would have saved months. Hereâ€™s the list: 1. Arrays & Hashing â€“ Build your basics - Group Anagrams - Top K Frequent Elements - Product of Array Except Self - Longest Consecutive Sequence - Valid Anagram 2. Two Pointers & Array Tricks â€“ Speed + logic - Sort Colors - Move Zeroes - Container With Most Water - Trapping Rain Water - Rotate Image - Merge Intervals 3. Sliding Window & Prefix â€“ Substring and subarray mastery - Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters - Minimum Window Substring - Subarray Sum Equals K - Maximum Points You Can Obtain from Cards - Car Pooling - Permutation in String 4. Stacks & Queues â€“ Where interviewers get tricky - Min Stack - Evaluate Reverse Polish Notation - Daily Temperatures - Sliding Window Maximum - Task Scheduler - Stock Price Fluctuation 5. Linked Lists & Design Patterns â€“ Must-know - Reverse Linked List - Merge Two Sorted Lists - Linked List Cycle II - Merge k Sorted Lists - LRU Cache - Insert Delete GetRandom O(1) 6. Trees & BST â€“ Recursion muscle - Diameter of Binary Tree - Binary Tree Maximum Path Sum - Trim a BST - Convert Sorted Array to BST - Populate Next Right Pointers II - Delete Nodes and Return Forest 7. Graphs & Traversals â€“ DFS, BFS, Topo Sort - Number of Islands - Rotting Oranges - Clone Graph - Course Schedule II - Bus Routes - Reconstruct Itinerary 8. Heaps & Greedy â€“ Optimize like a pro - K Closest Points to Origin - Kth Largest in Array & Stream - Furthest Building You Can Reach - Process Tasks Using Servers - Cheapest Flights Within K Stops 9. Dynamic Programming â€“ 1D â€“ The real jump in thinking - Maximum Subarray - Longest Increasing Subsequence - Coin Change II - Maximum Profit in Job Scheduling - Jump Game II - Unique BSTs II 10. Matrix / Trie / Advanced â€“ Tough but rewarding - Longest Increasing Path in a Matrix - Word Search II - Implement Trie - Clone Graph (DFS revisit) - Group Anagrams (hashing revisit) - Convert Sorted Array to BST (recursion revisit) This list is not for skimming. Solve them cleanly, and youâ€™ll not only gain confidence but also spot exactly where youâ€™re weak. And if you want structured guidance and breakdowns of these problems, my DSA prep course covers all of this step by step. You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve built for you: âœ… Notes that are concise and clear âœ… Most-asked questions per topic âœ… Real patterns + approaches to master them ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ² : Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B Whatsapp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: In 2025, DSA = Pattern recognition. I wish someone_110
posts.text: In 2025, DSA = Pattern recognition. I wish someone told me this before I spent months grinding 1000+ questions Hereâ€™s the shortcut I wish I had from Day 1: â™¦ï¸ When the input is an Array or String â€¢ Sorted? â†’ Binary Search, Two Pointers (e.g., pair sum, removing duplicates). â€¢ Count ways, maximize/minimize? - Dependent choices â†’ Dynamic Programming (subsets, knapsack, LIS). - Independent â†’ Greedy (interval scheduling, activity selection). â€¢ Feasibility or generate solutions? â†’ Backtracking (subsets, permutations, N-Queens). â€¢ String building / prefix checks? â†’ Trie, Stack, Monotonic Stack (valid parentheses, next greater element). â€¢ Search or frequency? â†’ HashMap / Set (subarray sum = K, frequency counting). â€¢ Continuous updates / fixed size or variable window? â†’ Sliding Window, â€¢ Counting Map (longest substring, anagrams). â€¢ Fast max/min extraction or running median? â†’ Heap, Monotonic Queue (top-K, priority tasks). â™¦ï¸ When itâ€™s a Graph â€¢ Fewest steps / shortest path? â†’ BFS, Dijkstra (unweighted vs weighted). â€¢ Explore all paths or detect cycles? â†’ DFS (connected components, topo sort). â€¢ Union-find or connectivity? â†’ DSU (minimum spanning tree, friend circles). â™¦ï¸ When itâ€™s a Tree â€¢ Level-based? â†’ BFS (zigzag, level order). â€¢ Depth-based? â†’ DFS (recursion, subtree sums). â€¢ Ancestor / LCA / path queries? â†’ Binary Lifting or Segment Trees. â™¦ï¸ When itâ€™s a Linked List â€¢ Detect loops? â†’ Fast & Slow Pointers (Floydâ€™s cycle detection). â€¢ Reverse / merge / reorder? â†’ Prev/Dummy Pointers, Recursion. This covers 90â€“95% of interview problems. Itâ€™s not about memorizing You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve built for you: âœ… Notes that are concise and clear âœ… Most-asked questions per topic âœ… Real patterns + approaches to master them ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ² : Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B Whatsapp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: I failed more than 20 coding interviews before I r_45
posts.text: I failed more than 20 coding interviews before I realized this: Solving hundreds of random Leetcode problems wasnâ€™t the answer. What finally worked? Focusing on the core building blocks that almost every question is based on. Hereâ€™s what I wish I had learned earlier: 1. Arrays - Arrays are everywhere in coding interviews. - Master sorting, binary search, two-pointers, sliding window, and prefix sums. - Get so good at these that solving them feels as easy as writing a `for` loop. 2. Decision Trees & Recursion - If you understand recursive decision trees, you can solve: âœ”ï¸ Binary Trees âœ”ï¸ Backtracking Problems âœ”ï¸ Combinatorics âœ”ï¸ Dynamic Programming âœ”ï¸ Some Graph Problems - Many tough problems break down into decision trees, train yourself to see them. 3. Graphs - Graphs seem complex, but most problems rely on DFS & BFS. - Learn how to apply them to matrix graphs and adjacency lists, the implementation is different. - Understand the edge cases: infinite loops, cycle detection, shortest path problems. 4. Hashmaps - If your solution is too slow, ask: Can a hashmap make this faster? - Use it for: âœ”ï¸ Counting frequencies (strings, arrays) âœ”ï¸ Quick lookups (O(1) time) âœ”ï¸ Graph adjacency lists 5. Heaps - Use min-heaps and max-heaps when you need to find the top K elements efficiently. - Insertion & deletion: O(log N) - Heapify (building a heap at once): O(N) (more efficient than inserting one by one). 6. Dynamic Programming: - DP is hard, but itâ€™s not as common in interviews as people think. - Focus on: âœ”ï¸ Longest Common Subsequence âœ”ï¸ Coin Change âœ”ï¸ Classic DP patterns (knapsack, LIS, partitioning) - Ignore ultra-complex DP problemsâ€”you likely wonâ€™t get them. Finally, Optimize for Efficiency, Not Exhaustion - You donâ€™t need 1000+ problems. - Focus on understanding concepts deeply, not just solving for the sake of it. - Smart preparation beats brute force every time. The biggest lesson? Depth > Quantity. Itâ€™s not about 500+ solved problems; itâ€™s about concept mastery. You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. Thatâ€™s what Iâ€™ve built for you: âœ… Notes that are concise and clear âœ… Most-asked questions per topic âœ… Real patterns + approaches to master them ğŸ‘‰ Grab the DSA Guide â†’ https://lnkd.in/d8fbNtNv ğ…ğ¨ğ« ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ ğƒğğ¯ ğˆğ§ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­ğ¬ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¢ğ§ ğŒğ² ğ‚ğ¨ğ¦ğ¦ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ² : Telegram - https://lnkd.in/d_PjD86B Whatsapp - https://lnkd.in/dvk8prj5 Built for devs who want to crack interviews â€” not just solve problems.

posts.id: Is DSA important for interviews? Yes, DSA (Data St_52
posts.text: Is DSA important for interviews? Yes, DSA (Data Structures and Algorithms) is very important for interviews, especially for software engineering roles. I often get asked, What do I need to start learning DSA? Here's the roadmap for getting started with Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA): ğ—£ğ—µğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğŸ­: ğ—™ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ—±ğ—®ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ğ˜€ 1. Introduction to DSA - Understand what DSA is and why it's important. - Overview of complexity analysis (Big O notation). 2. Complexity Analysis - Time Complexity - Space Complexity 3. Basic Data Structures - Arrays - Linked Lists - Stacks - Queues 4. Basic Algorithms - Sorting (Bubble Sort, Selection Sort, Insertion Sort) - Searching (Linear Search, Binary Search) 5. OOP (Object-Oriented Programming) ğ—£ğ—µğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğŸ®: ğ—œğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—ºğ—²ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—°ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ˜€ 1. Two Pointers Technique - Introduction and basic usage - Problems: Pair Sum, Triplets, Sorted Array Intersection etc.. 2. Sliding Window Technique - Introduction and basic usage - Problems: Maximum Sum Subarray, Longest Substring with K Distinct Characters, Minimum Window Substring etc.. 3. Line Sweep Algorithms - Introduction and basic usage - Problems: Meeting Rooms II, Skyline Problem 4. Recursion 5. Backtracking 6. Sorting Algorithms - Merge Sort - Quick Sort 7. Data Structures - Hash Tables - Trees (Binary Trees, Binary Search Trees) - Heaps ğ—£ğ—µğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğŸ¯: ğ—”ğ—±ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—»ğ—°ğ—²ğ—± ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—°ğ—²ğ—½ğ˜ğ˜€ 1. Graph Algorithms - Graph Representation (Adjacency List, Adjacency Matrix) - BFS (Breadth-First Search) - DFS (Depth-First Search) - Shortest Path Algorithms (Dijkstra's, Bellman-Ford) - Minimum Spanning Tree (Kruskal's, Prim's) 2. Dynamic Programming - Basic Problems (Fibonacci, Knapsack etc..) - Advanced Problems (Longest Increasing Subsea mice, Matrix Chain Subsequence, Multiplication etc..) 3. Advanced Trees - AVL Trees - Red-Black Trees - Segment Trees - Trie ğ—£ğ—µğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğŸ°: ğ—£ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—² ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğ—”ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» 1. Competitive Programming Platforms: LeetCode, CodeForces, HackerRank, CodeChef Solve problems daily 2. Mock Interviews - Participate in mock interviews to simulate real interview scenarios. - DSA interviews assess your ability to break down complex problems into smaller steps. You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus. posts.id: Key DSA Patterns You Actually Need for Cracking In_53
posts.text: Key DSA Patterns You Actually Need for Cracking Interviews at MAANG or FAANG or At Any Product Based Companies. ğŸ”¹ Arrays & Strings â€¢ Binary Search tricks (sorted arrays) â€¢ Sliding Window, Prefix Sum, DP (optimization) â€¢ Hashmaps/Sets (duplicates, frequency) â€¢ Subarray/Substring questions ğŸ”¹ Graphs â€¢ BFS, Dijkstra (shortest paths) â€¢ DFS, DSU (connectivity) â€¢ Topological Sort (dependencies) â€¢ Minimum Spanning Tree â†’ Kruskal, Primâ€™s ğŸ”¹ Linked Lists â€¢ Floydâ€™s Cycle Detection â€¢ Reversals & Rotations â€¢ Middle node & Intersection ğŸ”¹ Trees (Binary & BST) â€¢ Traversals: Inorder, Preorder, Postorder, Level-order â€¢ Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) â€¢ Balanced Tree checks â€¢ BST insert/search/delete ğŸ”¹ Dynamic Programming â€¢ Knapsack / Subset problems â€¢ Partitioning & Palindromes â€¢ LCS / Edit Distance â€¢ State-based DP: Paths, Games, Stocks ğŸ”¹ Stacks & Queues â€¢ Monotonic Stack/Queue (Next Greater Element, Sliding Window Max) â€¢ Min Stack, Valid Parentheses â€¢ Heaps / Priority Queues â€¢ Kth largest/smallest â€¢ Merging Intervals, Scheduling ğŸ”¹ Bit Manipulation â€¢ Subset generation â€¢ XOR tricks (unique/missing elements) This is what companies test â€” patterns, not 500+ random LeetCode problems. Once you can map a question to the right pattern, youâ€™re already 50% done. You need the right patterns, in the right order, with the right focus.
